Posts.Content: May 31, 2012 09:35PM Luvflsun wrote: Praying for your biopsy. My surgery is the 13th and it's very tough. I would not involve your daughter. With that said, my kids have to go with me because mine is out of town BUT the word Cancer is not mentioned and they will be able to be outside doing kids stuff because it is at that type of facility. I would not take her to the hospital where she had such a traumatic experience for anything regarding a worry about her mom. Mine do coloring contests and get prizes for most creative, most colorful, etc when I wake up. Then their drawings will hang as my get well art. Unless she has to be there and there is someone to keep her assured mom is ok and turn the time into childlike activities, I would not take her. Praying God will comfort you and your daughter. Xoxo
Posts.Title: Radiologist and Surgeon Disagree LisaDVM Shayne

Posts.Content: May 26, 2012 04:28PM Luvflsun wrote: My breast specialist at Mayo and radiologist agreed and my surgeon did not. It is so frustrating. I, too had to make a decision and it is very difficult with conflicting information. I had needle core biopsy and the bs and radiologist wanted lumpectomy. Said the needle biopsy would not be enough information because the lump is too large. Now I am having lumpectomy a year and several months later, then after healing and finding out it is not cancer (I hope) as they say it is not, then I have to undergo reconstruction. This is odd with the mixed advice and a tremendous amount to go through with mixed signals. I feel for you. I would say get another opinion but I just feel have the biopsy and piece of mind. I don't understand why I'm going under if it is not cancer. It makes no sense. See my post if you can and offer advice I am lost on this one. The first bs and radiologist wanted it out within 30 to 60 days and now the bs doesn't feel that way anymore and the surgeon who did not see what they saw in the beginning now does and would excise it if it were her body....it's like a big joke and nobody remembers how they felt yesterday regarding such a serious issue....let's just fly by the seat of our pants. Ugh I hope the best for you, this is tough, everyone wants to say stay positive and that is true but let's be real. This stuff is tough when we have to make decisions as mothers that will affect the rest of our/their lives. I've gone through stages where I feel a radiologist is the one to follow as they are trained to look, detect cancer PERIOD THAT IS their job, while a surgeon is trained in that but also much more to it obviously. But I am told at Mayo the surgeon trumps them all. Ugh

Posts.Content: Luvflsun wrote: Just a lump but worried. I keep getting moved to diagnosed or to surgery (on this site), but I am not at that stage yet. Yes, I found a lump many years ago, GYNE said it was thought to be benign. Then over a year ago Breast specialist and radiologist thought it looked suspicious because of its shape and bloody nipple discharge. The surgeon did not feel that way. She said unless the discharge is spontaneous not to worry and breasts are full of lumps and bumps. Now after repeated mammo and needle biopsy, which was benign, they have decided I should excise it because of its large size, assymetry, and density. I know it sounds like that means I am at the surgery stage, but I am NOT quite there. I am trying to find people with just a lump with pain radiating into chest and into their backs on only the side that you have the lump. And what did you and your drs decide to do? What did you feel and what outcome did you have? I have heard everything from surgery is drastic to get it out now. Any advice from people going through the I have a lump and what worry, thoughts, pains, decisions, that brings. Xo to all Log in to post a reply

It's funny and sounds dumb compared to the scare of cancer but if I get "that" news in a dirty house, I will be worse than if clean, totally a ridiculous obsession! Lol

I don't like the word wartlike (lol) but have read enough to know it is for the look of the cells just as they can be around the areloa but not be warts. Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2012 04:22PM Luvflsun wrote: I also get the lower pain and have cysts and have intermittent blood today and kind of have to believe there is a correlation with my breast issues and my ovarian cyst issues. Very painful lower right for me and although yes, they burst sometimes and are okay scientifically, they also can be bothersome and painful and affect our daily activities. I know my pain in that area sure does. I'm hoping after my lumpectomy my ovaries will stop producing these and things will quiet down a bit. That's hoping we both get benign results!!!! I truly hope that for you and am praying for all of us going through this mess and scare of the is it "C"!? Prayers your way. Sorry I don't have more answers regarding your exact situation but wanted to let you know I can relate on a few issues and one thing I felt was alone (with that said, my husband is great but alone as far as what I am feeling) and as one person told me on here, YOU are NOT alone! Xoxo
Posts.Title: I know it's all nothing, but... mirabile marie5890

Posts.Content: May 27, 2012 02:44AM Luvflsun wrote: Such great advice NWArtLady! I can't accept help at all and don't even know how to speak when it is is offered, it's ridiculous of me. I don't have BC but am having lumpectomy with reconstruction to check as I stated in a question on another post in the undiagnosed but worried section. But I have several other illnesses one involving the brain and need help. So I say from experience, I know how you feel but set yourself up to be in a good place, emotionally and physically that day, so you will not have that worry the day of your first chemo along with the worry you can't control. You can control knowing your kids are going to be picked up no matter what this does to you on that first day. My brother-in-law just finished chemo a few months ago for brain cancer (medulloblastoma) and had someone with him at every appt just even if he slept. I wish I was close, I would take you. People want to help. Obviously if we as strangers are willing, your neighbors and friends and people in your community should be more than willing! God bless you sweetheart!
